question.title: Extracting data from objects using Unsafe (bypassing the Security Manager0

node.contents: Its worth nothing that HotSpot turns many Unsafe "native" calls into intrinsic rather than using JNI. e.g. it can be just one machine code instruction.

astNode.text: Its worth nothing that HotSpot turns many Unsafe "native" calls into intrinsic rather than using JNI. e.g. it can be just one machine code instruction.

node.contents:
I am fully aware that I am doing is:
1) Unsafe, that I have no more guarantees, type safety, and that the JVM could therefore crash
2) That I could do similar operations using ByteBuffers or JNI
3) That Unsafe is an internal class and could well disappear.

node.contents: With this in mind, I am trying to extract the data from an array using Unsafe and reflection:

node.contents: I first find the field offset of the array:

astNode.text: I first find the field offset of the array:

elements.contents: public long findFieldOffset(Event event) { try { Class cl = event.getClass(); Field data_field = cl.getDeclaredField("data"); data_field.setAccessible(true); long offset = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(data_field); return offset; } catch (NoSuchFieldException e) { e.printStackTrace(); } return 0; }

units.rawText: public long findFieldOffset(Event event) { try { Class cl = event.getClass(); Field data_field = cl.getDeclaredField("data"); data_field.setAccessible(true); long offset = unsafe.objectFieldOffset(data_field); return offset; } catch (NoSuchFieldException e) { e.printStackTrace(); } return 0; }

node.contents:
I subsequently try to extract the array from the class Event, and copy it to a buffer (byte_offset is the result of findFieldOffset).
In the code below, the first part is just a test function and prints out the correct string, whilst the second part extracts what should be the array, but when testing returns garbage unicode values:

astNode.text:
I subsequently try to extract the array from the class Event, and copy it to a buffer (byte_offset is the result of findFieldOffset).
In the code below, the first part is just a test function and prints out the correct string, whilst the second part extracts what should be the array, but when testing returns garbage unicode values:

elements.contents: /* Testing */ active_buffer.getBuffer().position(1); active_buffer.getBuffer().put(event.getData()); active_buffer.getBuffer().position(1); active_buffer.getBuffer().get(tuple, 0, (int)tuple_size); System.out.println("Test1: " + new String(tuple)) ; /* Test1 prints out the correct string */ unsafe.copyMemory( (Object) event, byte_offset + base, (Object) null, active_buffer.getAddress() + 1, tuple_size); active_buffer.getBuffer().position(1); active_buffer.getBuffer().get(tuple, 0, (int)tuple_size); System.out.println("Test2: " + new String(tuple)); /* Garbage unicode values gets printed*/

comments.text: /* Test1 prints out the correct string */

node.contents: Can anyone see anything wrong with this code?

node.contents: Thanks. Good point. I now get Test1: name10000000000Bob000000000000YxzBUSPv Test2: ??dname10000000000Bob000000000000YxzBUSPv So it's a good start. Do you have any idea of how to access the memory location of the array directly (I could just do event.getData() and use that - which as you suggested works, but event.getData() is a fairly expensive call, so was hoping to get the memory reference directly)

astNode.text: Thanks. Good point. I now get Test1: name10000000000Bob000000000000YxzBUSPv Test2: ??dname10000000000Bob000000000000YxzBUSPv So it's a good start. Do you have any idea of how to access the memory location of the array directly (I could just do event.getData() and use that - which as you suggested works, but event.getData() is a fairly expensive call, so was hoping to get the memory reference directly)

node.contents: If you just want to get the `data` field you can access it via reflection, you don't need to use an Unsafe. If you want to use Unsafe, you can get access to the reference, you don't need to copy the contents of the byte[]. If you want to copy the contents of a `byte[]` you can use normal System.arrayCopy() like any other `byte[]`

astNode.text: If you just want to get the `data` field you can access it via reflection, you don't need to use an Unsafe. If you want to use Unsafe, you can get access to the reference, you don't need to copy the contents of the byte[]. If you want to copy the contents of a `byte[]` you can use normal System.arrayCopy() like any other `byte[]`

node.contents: You only need to use Unsafe to copy data to/from direct/native memory which you don't appear to need.

astNode.text: You only need to use Unsafe to copy data to/from direct/native memory which you don't appear to need.

node.contents: I'm copying data to native memory, and was trying to avoid the cost of doing event.getData first (or obtain it by reflection), and then copyMemory. To access the reference, are you basically saying to use getLong at byte_offset?

astNode.text: I'm copying data to native memory, and was trying to avoid the cost of doing event.getData first (or obtain it by reflection), and then copyMemory. To access the reference, are you basically saying to use getLong at byte_offset?

node.contents: As data is a field, it is either a primitive or a reference, in either case you cannot copy it somewhere and treat it as a byte[]

astNode.text: As data is a field, it is either a primitive or a reference, in either case you cannot copy it somewhere and treat it as a byte[]

node.contents: If data is a byte[] you need to treat this as the true object, not the Event.

astNode.text: If data is a byte[] you need to treat this as the true object, not the Event.
